subject: Fashion
title: Size Inclusivity Progress
description: A short lesson to help you apply Size Inclusivity Progress.

hook.text: Until 2017, no plus-size model had appeared on a mainstream Vogue cover in the magazine's 125-year history.

buildup.text: Fashion designed almost exclusively for sizes 0-8, ignoring the majority of actual women's bodies.

discovery.text: Brands that expanded their size rangeâ€”like Universal Standardâ€”saw sales jump 30% or more.

twist.text: But most 'inclusive' lines still stop at size 24. True inclusivity stays a marketing point, not reality.

climax.text: Size inclusivity is growing, but fashion still treats larger bodies as afterthought, not starting point.

punchline.text: Inclusivity that stops at size 24 isn't truly inclusive.

quiz.question: What happened when brands like Universal Standard expanded their size ranges?
options: Their existing customers complained and sales declined
Sales remained flat because the market for larger sizes was too small
Sales jumped by 30% or more, proving demand existed
